quoteLast: they started down the trail that led from Grand View into the depths of the fearful dip. And as they descended, following their guide, Bob found himself realizing the colossal size of everything connected with the rainbow-hued canyon walls.
title: The Saddle Boys in the Grand Canyon; or, The Hermit of the Cave
author: Carson, James, Captain

quoteFirst: Then went a walk up to One-Tree-Hill. Saw several hares. The Cuckoo was calling till after
quoteLast: . Noticed that the large white moths fluttered a long time in one spot above the corn. Wild pigeons go to roost sooner than rooks, apparently. Got back about 9.
title: William Sharp (Fiona Macleod): A Memoir Compiled by His Wife Elizabeth A. Sharp
author: Sharp, Elizabeth A. (Elizabeth Amelia), 1856-1932

quoteFirst: "Don't ask now, Selim, my brother, we must march," said Kalulu, and nothing more was said until
quoteLast: they stopped at a swamp to refresh themselves with water, when Kalulu setting down his bundle to drink, the cloth fell off one side, and exposed the head of a man.
title: My Kalulu, Prince, King and Slave: A Story of Central Africa
author: Stanley, Henry M. (Henry Morton), 1841-1904; Harral, Horace [Illustrator]; Zwecker, Johann Baptist, 1814-1876 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: I have been a member of the North Side group for about a year. I was at a meeting at Zepf’s Hall May 3, which lasted till eleven o’clock P.M. About
quoteLast: a man at the back door called out that all the men who belonged to the armed sections should go to 54 West Lake Street in the basement, where a meeting was to be held, and I saw a lot of members get up and leave the hall. I know Lingg belonged to the armed section.

quoteFirst: Any means of conveyance other than legs, ignorant in those days of defeat, was not to be thought of. We had just the necessary two shillings, and no more. So we set off to walk the (at least) fourteen miles from Harrow Weald to Vauxhall, timing ourselves to arrive there about
quoteLast: . Anthony danced all night. I took no part in that amusement, but contented myself with looking on and with the truly superb display of fireworks.

quoteLast: as you passed through the lodge gates. It was a chilly night—not an evening a man would be inclined to dawdle; why had you taken ten minutes to do a five-minutes’ walk? All along I realized that we had only your statement for it that the study window was ever fastened.
title: The murder of Roger Ackroyd
author: Christie, Agatha, 1890-1976

quoteFirst: On the 29th at eight a.m. the Mewstone was passed and the wind being fresh from South-West we rounded the South-East Cape
quoteLast: , and at sunset we were off Cape Frederick Hendrick, which is the northern head of Adventure Bay: between this and Quoin, or Sloping Island, we stood off and on during the night. At daylight we entered the Derwent River and anchored off Hobart town at seven o'clock in the morning.

quoteFirst: Sunday, Nov. 22d, was passed quietly. Up to this time the pickets had been relieved about
quoteLast: in the morning, but as many of the men had been badly wounded while performing this duty, the commanding officer decided to change the time for doing this work, to early morning before light, and this Sunday morning was chosen to make this change.
title: Battery D First Rhode Island Light Artillery in the Civil War

quoteFirst: The enemy was discovered before Warren reached Parker's store and he was ordered to attack; Getty and the Second Division of the Sixth Corps were sent to defend Warren's left flank and Wright with the First Division of the Sixth Corps was ordered up to Warren's right, and
quoteLast: Hancock was ordered to come to the support of Getty, all this happening where Grant had expected, at least had hoped for, an unopposed passage. Instead of a retreating enemy, Warren opened the great battle of the Wilderness by an attack upon a foe ready for the fray; but let the Fifth Corps Commander tell his own story:--
title: The Thirty-Ninth Regiment Massachusetts Volunteers, 1862-1865

quoteFirst: In many places our way was obstructed by trees that had been felled across; undoubtedly done by Bushwhackers, for in one place there lay the dead body of one, who had been caught in the act and slain by our advance. We went into camp, for the night,

quoteFirst: In the evening, we anchored under a fine bank, where a large leguminous tree was covered with clusters of pink and white flowers and large pale green flat pods. Venus and the moon were shining brilliantly, and the air was deliciously cool, when,
quoteLast: , we turned in under our tolda, but mosquitoes and sand-flies would not allow us to sleep for some hours. The next day we had a good wind and went along briskly; the river was narrower and had fewer islands; palms were less abundant than below, but the vegetation of the banks was equally luxuriant.
title: Travels on the Amazon
author: Wallace, Alfred Russel, 1823-1913

quoteFirst: As the house was so agreeable, and our next day's journey short, we could not prevail upon ourselves to leave the _Trojes_ before
quoteLast: ; and even then, with the hopes of spending some time there on our return to see the mining establishment; the mills for grinding ore, the horizontal water-wheels, etc., etc.; and still more, the beautiful scenery in the neighbourhood.
